qas.question: What is the global Jewish news service known as?
What is New Jersey's largest daily paper?
What term do media entities refrain from using?
Who is the spiritual leader of Temple Israel Community Center?
Where is the Temple Israel Community Center located?

plausible_answers.text: several media entities refrain from using the term "ultra-Orthodox"

qas.question: What did the New England press association claim?
How large is the global Jewish news service?
The Religion Newswriters Association was the first news source to drop what name?
What is a New York paper still using the term ultra-orthodox?
Who was the executive editor of the Star-Ledger?

context: According to the New Jersey Press Association, <b5_0>several media entities refrain from using the term <a2_0>"<b7_0>ultra-Orthodox<b7_0/><a2_0/>"<b5_0/>, including the Religion Newswriters Association; <a0_0>JTA<a0_0/>, the global Jewish news service; and <a1_0>the Star-Ledger<a1_0/>, <b6_0>New Jersey’s largest daily newspaper<b6_0/>. The Star-Ledger was the first mainstream newspaper to drop the term. Several local Jewish papers, including <b8_0>New York's Jewish Week<b8_0/> and Philadelphia's Jewish Exponent have also dropped use of the term. According to <a3_0><b9_0>Rabbi Shammai Engelmayer<b9_0/><a3_0/>, spiritual leader of Temple Israel Community Center in <a4_0>Cliffside Park<a4_0/> and former executive editor of Jewish Week, this leaves "Orthodox" as "an umbrella term that designates a very widely disparate group of people very loosely tied together by some core beliefs."
